comments: This class was taught as a weekly virtual seminar.
Reading material outside of class
None.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I have been exposed to a whole new selection of academic texts, resources, and ideas that I otherwise wouldn't have learned. I am really grateful to Maria's teaching style and her commitment to making sure everyone is learning and dedicated.

In this class, I learned about the different ideals and dreams of different Utopias, and the necessary components in order to foster such a stable society. Learning about utopias and dystopias, two extreme views of society, also gave a better perspective about the unique elements of our own society and government.
Interesting material and discussion on past conceptions of Utopias.
This course taught me new ways to think about the world.
I learned utopian and dystopian theory, applying it to modern day.

I learned a lot about the historical development of beliefs and religions in relation to 'Utopia', mainly through a philosophical outlook on historical readings. The discussion sections taught me how to further evaluate these readings and look deeper in the meaning of the texts and the beliefs of the authors.

I learned much of how the ideas of what makes a utopia or dystopia in the western world changed over human history. I learned that there is no such thing as a universal utopia, since what everyone values can vary so much. I also learned that utopias are often created and imagined to solve what people see as flaws in their society, while dystopias often are caricatures of contemporary issues take to extremes.

I learned about the history behind utopias and the different kinds. We learned about religious, more realistic utopias like Plato's Republic and more imaginary ones such as Cockaigne. We also learned about eco-socialist utopias and a little about the communist utopias. Dystopias were learned about but there were less examples studied and it wasn't as much of a focal point.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was truly spectacular. I have loved learning about utopias and dystopias from an academic point-of-view and can't wait to develop these ideas further. I appreciate Maria's ability to adjust readings or projects in order to facilitate the best learning environment for her students.

I thought the reading material for this course was long but very worthwhile. Each reading was carefully selected and brought up new utopian and dystopian ideals. I also thought Professor Jordan had great ideas and was overall a very nice, heartwarming, and understanding instructor, which is important during a unprecedented time such as now. It was interesting to learn how relevant these dystopian and utopian elements are in shaping our current society, and how we can make our society better in the future. However, I thought that sometimes the course materials were a little hard to find, and I wish there was a little more transparency on how we were doing in the class and where we could improve (ie. updating grades on Canvas).
The method of class discussion could have been improved upon to flow more smoothly.
Strength: Professor Jordan made the class feel very comfortable, and the conversation always flowed smoothly.

The class at its core is quite enjoyable if you're someone who likes worldbuilding and stuff like that. There were some last minute changes to the midterm and final though so perhaps it'd be better if those were put in place earlier on.

The strength lies in how interesting and engaging it was, especially with weekly blogs about our personal opinions on the readings. I think the only weakness would be a lack of evaluation on the writing.

Strengths of this course included the dystopia section and the presentations. I thought the presentations were a great way to explore the material in ways that we found interesting and created a lot of thought-provoking scenarios for the class to be able to answer. I think one of the weaknesses was the focus on utopias throughout the course and I think a way that can be improved is by simply exercising how the utopias could seem dystopic. For example, what about Plato's republic made it a dystopia or what about Thomas More's utopia made it a dystopia would have bene interesting to explore so that the class did not feel not feel so utopia centric.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought that because the course was online, it lended really well to student-led discussions and presentations. I also thought that because this course was so fluid and covered so many topics, the class was very flexible. The seminar format worked well, as everyone had their videos on and was contributing a lot to the course. The online discussions allowed students to think a little deeper into the text before the class.
The online seminar felt very open for conversation and strongly simulated the in-class environment.
Seeing as it was completely virtual, I think the course was very engaging.

The Zoom seminars succeeded for this course. I think the way they were organized was nice and although the time zones did not work out well for me, I managed to wake up for the seminar and get going. The breaks during the seminars were very welcome and helped to keep our energy up and our participation higher. The thing that could be improved is the Canvas engagement. For the discussion board, I know reminders shouldn't be necessary, but they were easy to forget about when they weren't mentioned and I never received any notifications when they were opened. It could be improved by possibly sending an email when the board is opened or maybe creating an announcement.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would HIGHLY recommend this course to another student. If you can't take this course, definitely try and take one that is taught by Maria Jordan.
I absolutely would not.

Yes! I would recommend this course to another student because I think that this seminar gave me a new way of thinking about the way things are in our government and society. The amount I learned in the course relative to the amount of work for the class was outstanding. Professor Jordan is very knowledgeable and adds very interesting perspectives to the conversation.
Yes, Professor Jordan wants everyone in the class to learn, and does all she can to facilitate success.
Yes! If you're interested in philosophy and ideologies, it's definitely a more relaxed and fun class to take.
Yes it is very interesting and the professor was passionate and engaging.

Yes, the class was always very engaging and interesting. The discussions were great at having people share their own viewpoints, and the different historical sources is a good in depth was of seeing how peoples views changed over time, despite being from largely the same regions and all being part of the western school tradtition.

I would recommend this course to students that are comfortable with the early seminar time and want to learn more about utopias. The utopia aspect is developed thoroughly and its interesting to see what people thought would be ideal in previous times. However, one of the greatest challenges for me was the time zone resulting in a 6am course which was difficult to accommodate for but it was manageable.
